results.title: Approach to infant education
results.creator_credit: Ron Saunders, Don Anderson and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Follows a day’s activities in a junior primary classroom and looks at how one teacher uses space and time in her teaching methods. The film also looks at the “vertical grouping” method of teaching.

results.title: Approach
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Salesmanship”.
A training film which stresses the importance of a well planned sales interview. Some of the factors that contribute to a good approach in selling are discussed. Stresses that a sales person must gain the interest, confidence, favourable attention, and positive interest of the prospective customer during the interview.

results.title: Apprenticeship: I wasn't made to be a secretary
results.creator_credit: David Haythornthwaite, Elisabeth Knight and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Girls who have chosen to serve apprenticeships in such areas as stonemasonry, automotive mechanics and painting discuss why they decided on these traditionally male dominated stress. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Applying a Therblig check list
results.brief_description: Illustrates how a Therblig checklist can be applied to jobs for the purpose of developing an improved method. The program demonstrates several jobs being performed and then applies the appropriate check list question for the purpose of devising an improved method.

results.title: Application of Pascal's Law. Part 1. The Hydraulic jack
results.creator_credit: United States. Navy. Bureau of Aeronautics
results.brief_description: The film reviews Pascal’s Law, and studies the input and output pistons and the system in actual motion. Demonstrates how work is done by means of a hydraulic system and how the amount of work performed is measured.
results.title_for_label: Application of Pascal’s Law. Part 1. The Hydraulic jack

results.title: Appleseed
results.creator_credit: Kazuyoshi Katayama, Masaki Sawanobori, Atsushi Sugita, Taro Maki and Manga Entertainment
results.brief_description: A dark, cyberpunk anime set far in the future. World War Three has plunged society into a state of anarchy. To try and resolve the problems created by war, the remaining governments band together to create Olympus, an experimental city designed as a sanctuary for the surviving humanity. However, this new paradise is also home to a new species, the Bio-Droid, a cyborg slave specifically created to administer the city. Some of the citizens are extremely unhappy with this brave new world, and long for liberty - at any price. After terrorists try to destroy the city, special SWAT teams are called in to try and neutralise the situation. Terrorist AJ Sebastian manages to escape from police custody by murdering an officer. Horrified by what has occurred, police offider Dunan Nats and her cyborg partner, Buliaros Hekatonecles, transfer to investigations in order to hunt down and arrest him, before he has the chance to destroy Olympus. A fast-paced anime, filled with heavy weaponry, fascinating mecha, and enough references to characters and places in Greek mythology for the viewer to get a clear sense of the underlying concerns of this animation. This film is based on an original story by Masamune Shirow, who published the first book in the Appleseed series “The Promethean Challenge”, in 1985. In 1986, the Appleseed books won him the Galaxy Award for the best sci-fi manga. In general, Shirow’s inspiration derives from reading extensively, particularly in the areas of science, medicine, the supernatural, military strategy, biology, nanotechnology, and mythology, which is particularly apparent in Appleseed.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kazuyoshi Katayama, Masaki Sawanobori, Atsushi Sugita, Taro Maki and Manga Entertainment

results.title: Apples in Tasmania
results.creator_credit: Fred Whatham and Cine Austral Productions
results.brief_description: Traces the development and locations of the apple-growing industry in Tasmania. Illustrates activities related to the planting, culture, harvesting and marketing of apples. Narrated by Roger Climpson. Suitable for Upper Primary-Upper Secondary students.
